title: Rapist used fake ID to bag top building jobs and may have had keys to new homes
text:

A double rapist faked his ID three times to bag senior jobs on building sites across Britain.

Nicholas Harding was jailed for eight years at Oxford crown court in 2009 for raping a businesswoman.

The monster pounced as she walked home in the dark and left her naked and sobbing in the snow.

He also attacked three prostitutes, raping one, and broke into houses to steal women’s underwear.

After his release he used bogus ID to get work as a building manager.

(Image: Getty)

Industry insiders fear the sex beast, now 52, may have had access to keys at incomplete family homes.

His last job was senior site manager for Barratt at a 382-home development in Buckingham, Bucks.

He was sacked last week after it is understood he accidentally gave ­workmates his real name.

A source said: “One of the lads ­working with him searched the internet to find him. They couldn’t believe what they found. He was kicked off site.

“It’s a scandal that Harding was able to get a job which could have given him the keys to residential properties.”

He also used false ID to con his way into a job at St Modwen Homes’ St Andrews Park development, Uxbridge, West London, but was ­booted out ­after they rumbled him. Harding is also believed to have worked at Persimmon’s The Oaks project in Bicester, Oxfordshire.

One new homeowner – who has two young children – said: “It’s terrifying that a rapist with such a horrific record could blag that access.”

Harding was brought to justice for raping the businesswoman 24 years after it happened thanks to DNA tests.

His victim said her life had been wrecked by Harding, who threatened to kill her during her ordeal.

Barratt’s Buckingham development is at an early stage with no complete houses. The firm said: “An individual was employed after giving a false ­identity. As soon as that came to our attention he was immediately suspended and left the business.”

St Modwen Homes said it was ­technically plausible but highly unlikely Harding could have copied keys.

Persimmon declined to comment.
description: EXCLUSIVE: Nicholas Harding had previously been convicted for attacking a woman as she walked home
